fields.headline: Pricewatch West Midlands
fields.bodyText: · The average property price in the West Midlands is £142,635 (compared with British average of £147,785) - up 18.8 per cent over the year (compared with a UK rise of 18.5 per cent), says the Halifax. · In Birmingham's Barnt Green 'A lot more property is coming on to the market but there is much overpricing,' says Andrew Oulsnam of Robert Oulsnam & Co. · In Burton upon Trent, 'the market is relatively buoyant,' says John Stevenson of John German. 'The buy-to-let market is particularly strong.' · In Hereford and surroundings, a 'shortage of quality town and country property is still pushing prices up,' says Paul Morris of Jackson Estate Agents. · In Nuneaton, 'Reality is starting to bite over £200,000 where sellers realise the need for competitive pricing if they are serious about selling,' says Roy Hawkins of Hawkins. · Wolverhampton is still seeing 'keen interest and inquiries', says surveyor Stuart Swash. 'There is some resistance if asking prices are too bullish.' · The average property takes 3.9 weeks to sell after 8.9 viewings and fetches 96.1 per cent of the asking price, according to Hometrack. · The number of properties for sale is down 18 per cent over the last year, according to the Royal Institution for Chartered Surveyors (RICS). · Rents average £395 per month for one-bedroom flats, says the RICS. Two-beds average £475; three-bed semis £585; and four-bed detached properties £750.
